{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3322377,"name":"","username":"crueter","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/crueter/{size}/258043_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-03T03:36:33.809Z","cooked":"

In case the title wasn’t obvious we are using CTRE’s swerve project generator.

Occasionally, whenever we deploy (about 20% of the time), upon enabling in teleop or auto we see one module (rarely two modules) start spinning randomly and uncontrollably. We think the CANCoders know they’re incorrect, but still spin randomly regardless.

We checked the self test in Phoenix Tuner X, and saw that all the configs looked normal, but we saw a Fused Sensor Out of Sync sticky fault on the steer motor. That’s the only thing that looked remotely different.

We intend to test this with a new, blank swerve project but haven’t gotten around to it yet. I’ll update this thread when we do.

We’re unsure of the exact timeline. It’s been an issue for the entire time that I’ve been involved in robot code (end of January) but it was apparently happening before my involvement as well.

Here’s a link to our code.

GitHub

GitHub - Team4028/2024-Crescendo: Team 4028's robot code for the 2024 FRC season

Team 4028's robot code for the 2024 FRC season. Contribute to Team4028/2024-Crescendo development by creating an account on GitHub.

Any help is appreciated.

We’ve verified that whenever we enable, the “Fused Sensor Out of Sync” fault shows up.

I tried making the swerve motors configure themselves with a delay of 500ms from each other. So far after 10 tries everything seems good.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2024-03-03T06:02:51.012Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":7,"reads":69,"readers_count":68,"score":48.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":457010,"topic_slug":"ctre-swerve-modules-occasionally-spin-randomly-upon-deploy-bootup","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50684,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"6032 | QDash"},"post_url":"/t/ctre-swerve-modules-occasionally-spin-randomly-upon-deploy-bootup/457010/4","custom_user_title":"6032 | QDash","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3322454,"name":"","username":"crueter","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/crueter/{size}/258043_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-03T06:21:51.281Z","cooked":"

This seems to have solved it! Hasnt happened after 30 or so tries.

250ms delay works just as well. Since the CAN Timeout is 100ms by default if I remember correctly, I’d say 250 is still a safe bet.

The idea behind this is that when your code initializes, you’re trying to configure a million motors at a time, so your CAN utilization goes through the roof (verified to be >90%). This can cause some motors to miss their configs, which would explain our fused sensor fault.

This is the solution i ended up using:

github.com

Team4028/2024-Crescendo/blob/abs-encoder-climber/src/main/java/frc/robot/subsystems/CommandSwerveDrivetrain.java#L106


      
    
          
  1. }

    2. 
          
  2. 

    3. 
          
  3. public CommandSwerveDrivetrain(SwerveDrivetrainConstants driveTrainConstants, SwerveModuleConstants... modules) {

    4. 
          
  4.     super(driveTrainConstants, modules);

    5. 
          
  5.     if (Utils.isSimulation()) {

    6. 
          
  6.         startSimThread();

    7. 
          
  7.     }

    8. 
          
  8.     configModules(modules);

    9. 
          
  9. }

    10. 
          
  10. 

    11. 
          
  11. private void configModules(SwerveModuleConstants... modules) {

    12. 
          
  12.     int i = 0;

    13. 
          
  13.     for (SwerveModuleConstants module : modules) {

    14. 
          
  14.         try {

    15. 
          
  15.             Thread.sleep(250);

    16. 
          
  16.         } catch (InterruptedException e) {

    17. 
          
  17.             System.err.println("bad" + e.getMessage());

    18. 
          
  18.         }

    19. 
          
  19. 

    20. 
          
  20.         TalonFXConfiguration talonConfigs = new TalonFXConfiguration();

    21. 
          
  21. 

    22.

Sleeps are no issue in the constructor, no loops are running so you can’t get overruns.

For us it was a little hacky, but for teams who use their own swerve code this should be way easier.
